content: There is no 1:1 mapping between tests and validators. They should check the same thing.

No, CodinGame does *NOT* trim the answer. So I remove the clumsy note, and I patch the outputs and the solution in Pyhton.

Apart from this point, it is a really nice problem.
Rare style puzzle. An you may better set an upper limit of N?

This is interesting, but I think it's a bit too convoluted. Here are some of my problems with it:

First, there are really two separate puzzles in here: the deciphering of binary numbers, and the formatting and display of a grid of numbers. They aren't really thematically connected to each other, and it feels like I'm just solving two separate puzzles.

The output format isn't obvious until I look at the example, but in the IDE, I can only see a single example, of a 2x2x2 grid. I didn't realize that you were expecting symmetrical dimensions (1x1x1, 2x2x2, 3x3x3, etc.) until I looked at multiple examples.

The 0-bit test isn't at all intuitive (at least not to me), and if you get it wrong in the IDE, it doesn't really show you what is expected.

Alright thanks, I just thought it seemed a bit too easy with straight up numbers being input, but I see your point, I'll also call it a cube instead of grid to make it a bit more clear that it's evenly sized.

I wasn't sure if you're supposed to set an upper limit or not haha, technically it should work with any value for N, but I can't fit a 5x5x5 grid in the output so it'll always be below that, I'll update it :)

Thanks a bunch, it did when I wrote the question though haha. Quick question, do you think updating the question for non regular sizes would work (eg. a block of size 2x4x3), or would it make it a bit over complicated?
I am personally more troubled because of the varying size of the text we need to write on the squares.

I agree with just about everything in this comment.

(I may be too late to debate binary numbers)

There's no need for the mismatch between the cube volume and the number of inputs. There's no need for the special case for 0 (0^3 = 0, that's no number at all (this fits) and zero volume hence no cube at all (this doesn't)). There's no reason for the front right vertical edge to obscure other edges but not numbers.

(and that leading period is still ridiculous, but that's not your fault)

Thanks, good point about the empty cube, I was just trying to think up enough different tests but it is a bit useless, I'll remove that bit. 
As to the mismatch in size, the idea was to catch people out with relying on using the simple "n^(1/3)". I can't remember which size it is, but there was a rounding error I encountered which caused a cube to display one level lower.  I guess it's not important anyway so I'll drop that bit out too.

With the vertical edge going over other edges but not numbers, that was just a choice in style that I thought looked best, as it is technically over everything, but you still want to see the numbers :)
